title: 107_hr4879
content:
The Act titled "Veterans' Employment, Business Opportunity, and Training Act of 2002" references Title 38, United States Code. Title I focuses on Employment Services and includes definitions. The Act "Veterans' Employment, Business Opportunity, and Training Act of 2002" defines terms such as "veteran" and "eligible person" in reference to Title 38, United States Code. The term "veteran" aligns with the definition in section 4211(4) of Title 38, while an "eligible person" includes the spouse of a service-connected disability deceased person or an active duty member listed under specific categories for more than ninety days. The term "State" includes several States of the United States, the District of Columbia, and Puerto Rico, with the possibility of including other territories as determined necessary. The term "servicemember" refers to an individual in the Armed Forces being separated within specified time periods. Establishment of a national performance-based job-search assistance program to help veterans, servicemembers, and eligible individuals find and maintain employment. The program will also aid employers in hiring qualified individuals. The Department of Veterans Affairs will utilize web-based technology to improve services for veterans globally. Additionally, a new competitive grants program will be established. The Secretary of Veterans Affairs will establish the "Veterans' Employment, Business Opportunity and Training Program" (VEBOT) to provide employment services to veterans, servicemembers, and eligible individuals. Regulations will be implemented to determine eligibility criteria and address program development and implementation. The Veterans' Employment, Business Opportunity and Training Program (VEBOT) will provide employment services to veterans, servicemembers, and eligible individuals. The program will determine the nature of services, means of providing them, monitoring performance, cooperation with State employment agencies, coordination with the Department of Labor, and program administration within the Department of Veterans Affairs. The Veterans Affairs will administer the VEBOT program, with regulations developed considering task force recommendations and consultation with the Secretary of Defense. A task force will be established to make recommendations within 180 days, including representatives from various organizations. Grants under the program will be competitive and include performance requirements. The VEBOT program under the Veterans Affairs will be administered through competitive grants with performance requirements. States or entities receiving funds must meet agreed-upon performance measures, with the option to request adjustments in case of unforeseen circumstances. Failure to meet requirements may result in assistance from the Secretary of Veterans Affairs. The VEBOT program under the Veterans Affairs will be administered through competitive grants with performance requirements. States or entities receiving funds must comply with cost principles and utilize wage record information for program performance measurement. Failure to meet requirements may result in funds being removed and a new grantee being solicited through competition. The grantee must adhere to uniform-cost principles and fiscal controls for proper disbursal of Federal funds. They must also comply with administrative requirements and take corrective action if service providers are not in compliance with the Act. The grantee must adhere to fiscal controls and take corrective action if service providers fail to comply. The Secretary may remove funds from the grantee and solicit a new provider if corrective action is not taken. Up to 15% of funds can be used for administration costs, and the Secretary can reserve up to 25% of funding for pilot projects. The available funding for grants is for financing national-level primary services and creating pilot programs to establish the effectiveness of innovative program designs and service delivery systems. SEC. 104. TRANSFER OF RESPONSIBILITY FOR ADMINISTRATION OF CERTAIN EMPLOYMENT SERVICES TO SECRETARY OF VETERANS AFFAIRS. During a specified period, responsibilities related to employment services under certain sections of title 38, United States Code, will be transferred from the Secretary of Labor to the Secretary of Veterans Affairs. This includes the functions of the Assistant Secretary of Labor for Veterans' Employment and Training and necessary personnel. Coordination between the two departments will facilitate the transfer of these functions. The administration of employment services under chapter 41 of title 38, United States Code, will be transferred to disabled veterans' outreach programs specialists and local veterans' employment representatives. SEC. 105. REPEAL OR AMENDMENT OF EXISTING AUTHORITIES. Repeal of various sections related to veterans' employment and training services, with amendments to align with the Department of Veterans Affairs. Amendments are made to replace references to the Secretary of Veterans Affairs with the Secretary of Labor in various paragraphs related to veterans' employment and training services. Amendments replace references to the Secretary of Veterans Affairs with the Secretary of Labor in paragraphs related to veterans' employment and training services. TRANSFER OF RESPONSIBILITY FOR ADMINISTRATION OF TRANSITION ASSISTANCE PROGRAM TO THE SECRETARY OF VETERANS AFFAIRS. References to the Secretary of Labor and the Secretary of Veterans Affairs in section 1144 of title 10, United States Code are interchanged. Section 1144(d) is amended to allow the use of personnel of grant recipients or other personnel determined appropriate by the Secretary of Veterans Affairs, as long as it does not significantly interfere with services to eligible veterans and other recipients. TITLE III--HOMELESS VETERANS' REINTEGRATION PROGRAMS

SEC. 301. Transfer of responsibility for administration of homeless veterans' reintegration program to the Secretary of Veterans Affairs. Section 2021 is amended by replacing "Secretary of Labor" with "Secretary of Veterans Affairs" and redesignating subsection (d) as subsection (c).

TITLE IV--EFFECTIVE DATE

SEC. 401. Effective date. The provisions of this Act shall become effective on October 1, 2002.
